_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?
body:
Nice to see you! First we need to tackle the big question: Do I have what it takes to start a business? 


Let's start by getting one thing clear. Nobody can say for sure if your idea can become a successful business. If you want to find out, you have to try.


But there are ways to better predict your chances. Below you can out how to ask and answer the three big questions about any business idea: why this idea? why me? and why now?
title: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?

_items.title: Desirability
_items.body: Your idea needs to solve a clear need that people have. Your first reality check is to find out whether people actually face the problem you are aiming to solve.

You need to have the confidence that you can deliver, or will be able to, on the solution you imagine. Your second reality check is to consider if you will be able to solve the problem people are facing.
_items.title: Feasability
Viability
_items.body: You need to make sure the cost of solving people's problem is less than they are willing to pay. Your final reality check is to consider whether you can cover the costs of solving the problem from what you expect to be paid.

displayTitle: Giving your idea a reality check
body:
As the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla said: 'Nobody will pay you for solving a non-problem.'


So can you decide if you idea is a problem worth solving? There are three main reality checks your idea needs to pass. Click on the boxes below to find out more.
title: Giving your idea a reality check

body: Even if your idea passes the reality check, itâ€™s likely someone else had a similar thought. These are potential competitors. For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A valuae proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. A good one will say how you solve the probelm and why your solution is the best available.
displayTitle: Making sure your idea is unique
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Making sure your idea is unique

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

title: Media Title

_items.body:
Seeking opportunity


Entrepreneurs see problems as opportunities. They also don't like leaving these opportunities for someone else to pursue.


Do you look at problems in your life and instantly think about how to solve them?

Taking risks before security


Entrepreneurs take a risk on a future business rather than looking for a safe job today.


Are you a 'poker player' who is willing to take measured risks to secure future returns?

Tolerating Failure


Entrepreneurs fail often but never let that failure deter them.


Do you have the desire to experiment, fail and keep going?

Creatively leveraging resources


Entrepreneurs often have to do without the right talent and improvise solutions with what they have.


Do you have the ability to get what you need from your friends and network?

Tenacity to overcome obstacles


Entrepreneurs regularly have to deal with doubt and uncertainty over their future.


Do you have the passion and persistence to learn from the inevitable set-backs and drive ideas into action?

displayTitle: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you
body:
You may have a great idea, but are you the person who should be making it into a business? After all being an entrepreneur isnâ€™t for everyone. So how can you decide if this idea is a good match for you?


There are some key traits many startup founders share. Scroll through them below and think about how many you have.
title: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you

body:
Successful businesses can spot can spot when a change creates new opportunities. Nokia was originally a paper mill, Sony sold radios and Mitel was a maker of lawnmowers. All of them saw a change and identified an opportunity to succeed.


For your idea to be successful, you will need to think carefully about this. What has changed in the world that will influence people to buy from you? It might be that you offer a brand new technology, solve a new problem or make something more affordable and practical.


Whatever the change, you need to be clear on how the world today will contribute to making your business a success. Having a clear answer to this question will boost your odds of success.
title: Getting the timing right

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s Right!


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

body: Can you find one of the criteria that you would use to give your new business idea a reality check?
instruction: Select any one of the options that match then click submit!
title: Taking a reality check

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem. There are lots of other ways of putting this but thinking about a solution and a problem is an easy way to remember!

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s right!


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem.

body: Earlier we learned how a value proposition helps you nail down your idea. But how would you define the idea if someone asked you?
instruction: Fill in the blanks in the sentence below then click submit
title: Nailing that value proposition

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Hit 'show answer' to check out our definitions.
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Hit 'show answer' to check out our definitions.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


You know those skills like the back of your hand!

_dropZones.text: You look at problems and see the solutions
You are willing to take a risk for a future return
You can improvise solutions where none exist
You move on fast from your mistakes

displayTitle: Taking a look in the mirror
body: While every entrepreneur is different, many share a particular set of traits. Can you match up the names of the trait to their descriptions?
instruction: Drag the titles onto the images then click submit
title: Taking a look in the mirror

body:
Well done! you've finished your first module.

Everything we've learnt above is important when considering if your idea has what it takes to become a business. We recommend taking some time to consider why this idea? why me? why now? and what next? They will give you the foundation on which your business is built.


So what happens once you have answers you need? The next thing you need is to take a closer look at those ideas. In the next module we will give you the skills to generate new business ideas and evaluate those you have.
title: You have what it takes!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: How can I come up with new ideas?
body: In this module we are going to look at how you can better manage your business ideas. Generating ideas then refining them is a discipline which successful entrepreneurs practice regularly. Learning how to manage your ideas process will help you make the most of your time.
title: How can I come up with new ideas?

body:
Making an idea into a reality needs energy and commitment. To keep this energy going even when things get tough, you need to love what youâ€™re doing. So itâ€™s important that we look carefully at our ideas to understand what 'turns us on' about this specific opportunity.


Remember that passion is infectious. If you really care about your idea, it will make it much easier to convince your first customers and your partners why they should too.
title: Staying interested

displayTitle: How to find ideas you are passionate about
body: We know that we need ideas we care deeply about to turn them into good businesses. So what strategies can we use to find these ideas? Neil Lurie, an expert on idea creation, suggests in his handbook that there are four ways to find ideas you are passionate about:

_items.title: Doing what you love
_items.body: What do you enjoy doing in your own time? If something interests you in your own life, chances are it will interest you as a business!
Do you face a regular frustration you canâ€™t find a solution too? Many successful ideas come for entrepreneurs creating solutions to their own problems.
_items.title: Solving your own problem
Using your expertise
_items.body: Is there a subject you are really expert in? Your edge in understanding might be a great source of new ideas.

_items.title: Borrowing from another community
_items.body: Have you seen a good idea somewhere else? Often we will come across good ideas in another country or sector that isnâ€™t around where you are.

title: How to find ideas you are passionate about

_incorrect.body: Incorrect answer, click continue to try again
_incorrect.title: Incorrect

_items.optionText: So sports review decided to do what they love. How about this next founder?
So BioBean adapted an existing technology to a new market. Another kind of bright idea!

body: In this section we'll introduce more founders who have identified new opportunities and taken action to bring them to reality.
instruction: Press play then click the buttons when prompted
title: Let's hear from some founders

_items.body:
Develop your understanding


You need to understand the market, the target audience, the technology and the the problem as deeply as you can.

Observe real people in real-life situations


Check your understanding against ordinary people. Find out what makes them tick, what confuses them, what they like, what they hate and how they feel about things.

Visualise the idea


Bring your ideas to life visually so that others can see and understand whatâ€™s in your brain.

Prototype rapidly


Quickly build, test and discard a series of working models to figure out what works for people, what doesnâ€™t and what confuses them.

Implement your idea


Bring the new idea to market rapidly. Then go back to developing your understanding.

body:
Very few successful business ideas are born fully-formed. Your understanding of what customers need and your ideas for solutions will evolve as your business grows. This process of learning something new about the world then changing your thinking is at the centre of what entrepreneurs do.


Tom Kelly, the founder of IDEO, sets out a five step process for idea refinement:
title: How to refine your ideas

body:
Developing and testing your ideas is an essential skill for any entrepreneur. Thankfully, there is a framework to help you work. Itâ€™s called â€˜effectual entrepreneurshipâ€™.


The framework is a series of steps to follow at regular intervals as you start your business. Each time you follow the steps, you can update your business model canvas to keep track of each iteration and to help highlight critical uncertainties or risks that we should try to address next.
displayTitle: Testing your ideas in the real world
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Testing your ideas in the real world

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

title: Media Title

body: There are four main strategies for generating ideas that spark your interest. Which of the following is one of them?
instruction: Select your answer and click submit.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Creating a solution to a problem you faced is a great way to find an idea that sparks your passion. If you can sympathise with the problem, you are much more likely to have the energy needed to create a solution!

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s Right!


Creating a solution to a problem you faced is a great way to find an idea that sparks your passion. If you can sympathise with the problem, you are much more likely to have the energy needed to create a solution!

title: Finding ideas you love

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


According to Tom Kelly, you should always start with developing your understanding then observe real people before visualising your idea, prototyping rapidly and finally implementing your idea.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


According to Tom Kelly, you should always start with developing your understanding then observe real people before visualising your idea, prototyping rapidly and finally implementing your idea.

_items.text: Observe real people in real-life situations

body: Refining your ideas is a discipline which all entrepreneurs can practice. According to Tom Kelly of IDEO, there are five main steps in this process. Can you place these steps in the correct order?
instruction: Arrange your answers in the correct order and click submit
title: Refining your ideas

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Prof. Saras Sarasvathy came up with the term 'effectual entrepreneurship' to describe the process of testing out new ideas in the real world.

_feedback.correct:
That's Right?


Prof. Saras Sarasvathy came up with the term 'effectual entrepreneurship' to describe the process of testing out new ideas in the real world.

body: Testing out your new ideas is a process you can repeat continuously as you start to introduce your business to the world. What is this process called?
instruction: Select your answer then click submit
title: Testing out those new ideas

body:
Great work! Developing and refining your ideas is a really important discipline for entrepreneurs. By practicing the approaches we've learned above, you can quickly improve your thinking and decide which ideas to pursue. Want some practice developing your ideas, why not complete this idea generation tool for an interactive look at your thoughts.


So how can we really think through our good ideas? In any business, there is a lot to think about from how we get to our customers to where we make money. In the next module we will introduce a framework to help you organise these thoughts.
title: You can refine your ideas!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: How can I test if my idea can become a business?
body:
Welcome back! In the last module we learnt how to decide whether your idea could become a business. 


In this module, you will learn the techniques for building a business model around your idea.
title: How can I test if my idea can become a business?

displayTitle: Turning an idea into a business model
body:
The process of turning an idea into a business requires us to get practical. We need to consider things like who will our customers be, what will we do and how will we make money? The way we answer these questions is by creating a business model.


According to the Financial Times, a business model is â€˜the method or means by which a company tries to capture value from its businessâ€™. In simpler terms, a business model sets out what our business plans to do, who for and how we will make money from it.


Your business model will guide every action your business takes, from making a product to sales and marketing.
title: Turning an idea into a business model

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

title: Media Title

body:
To help you make your own business model for your idea, we are going to use a tool called the business model canvas. The canvas is a simple and popular way of organising all your ideas about a business.


Remember in the last module when we learned that good business ideas need to be desirable, feasible and viable? Well the business model canvas helps us dig deeper into those criteria and think about the logic of how our business will work.
instruction: Below you can have a look at the canvas itself. But first, click on the video to the right to learn more about how the canvas works...
title: Organising your thoughts

_items.body: These are the people you want to reach in your business. They are the ones who are going to buy from you and whose lives you hope to improve.
_items.title: Customers
Value proposition
_items.body: This is your solution to your customerâ€™s problem. Whoever you are selling to, this is your explanation for why they should buy from you.
This describes how customers will learn about your business, how they will buy from you and how you will deliver your solutions to them.
_items.title: Channels

_items.body: This looks at what kind of relationship you are going to have with people. Are you something they canâ€™t live without or something they only buy once?
_items.title: Relationships
Revenue
_items.body: This looks at all the ways you will make money from your customers.

_items.title: Activities
_items.body: This section describes the main things you will be doing in your business. They might be day-to-day or more unique.
These are the things you will need to be in business including your products, your team and anything else important to you.
_items.title: Resources

_items.body: These are the people who will help your business succeed. Think about whose help you might need.
_items.title: Partnerships

_items.body: This looks at how much it will cost to run the business.
_items.title: Costs

body: Below is the business model canvas, divided into the 9 elements we saw in the video.
instruction: Click on the + button in each box to learn more
title: Exploring the canvas

_items.backText:
Demographics

Using this approach you can segment customers by their background. You might use age, income or location. This approach helps you target customer channels and activities.

Behaviour

Using this approach you can segment customers based on how they will interact with your business. You might use membership tiers, frequency of use or amount of money spent. This approach helps you target your customer relationships and revenue.

Needs

Using this approach you can segment customers by what problem they want to solve. You might use their daily lives or their long-term goals as a guide. This approach helps you target value proposition and partnerships.

body:
As we learned in the video, every canvas starts with the customers. Your new business may appeal to everyone but, as a new startup, your resources will be very limited. So itâ€™s important to be specific about your customers. This will help you design an even better business model.


But how should you split customers up? Below are three different ways to help you divide your customers more precisely.
instruction: Click on each icon below to discover more
title: Nailing your customer profiles

body:
Honing your business model skills


Now you have the skills to create a business model canvas. Like any new skill, business modelling is a question of practice. Remember, there is no limit to the number of business models you can create! It's a good idea to complete a few trail canvases before turning your attention to your own idea.


Try building a canvas using a business you know well. Try to select a business of which you are a customer, that way you can understand that business even better.


You can do this using pens and post-it notes or try either Canvanizer & BMG, which are free online tools.


If youâ€™d like, you can submit your completed canvas below to go along with your course records.
title: Honing your business model skills

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Some of those weren't quite what we thought. Not to worry, you can always use the handy guide above if you need to refresh your memory.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Some of those weren't quite what we thought. Not to worry, you can always use the handy guide above if you need to refresh your memory.

_feedback.correct:
Well done!


You clearly know your customer segments from your cost structure. You're well on the way to becoming a business modelling pro.

_items.text: This is your solution to your customerâ€™s problem. Whoever you are selling to, this is your explanation for why they should buy from you.
These are the people who will help your business succeed. Think about whose help you might need.
This looks at all the ways you will make money from your customers.
This section describes the main things you will be doing in your business. They might be day-to-day or more unique.

displayTitle: Getting to grips with the canvas
body: We've learned about what each of the nine building blocks of the business model canvas cover. Can you match the purpose to the building blocks?
title: Getting to grips with the canvas

body: There are several ways to segment your customers more clearly. Can you complete the following sentences about each of them?
instruction: Fill in the blanks in the sentence below then hit submit

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s right!


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem. There are lots of other ways of putting this but thinking about a solution and a problem is an easy way to remember!

_items.prefix: If you are dividing customers up based on their age, income or location you are using
When you think about customers based on how much they might spend you are using
Using the problems your customers face to put them into groups would be segmenting by

title: Getting your customer segments right

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Remember there's no limit to the number of canvases you can create. Things change and your business model may need to change too. Make a new canvas any time you have a significant change in your business.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Remember there's no limit to the number of canvases you can create. Things change and your business model may need to change too. Make a new canvas any time you have a significant change in your business.

_items.text: When we first start out. After that it will be smooth sailing!
After a few years. we can figure it out once we've in business...
If an investor asks for one. Not much point otherwise!
Whenever we see a change in our business. We'll create one and then keep updating it...

displayTitle: Creating your own business model canvas
body: We've learned how important a business model can be. When do you think you should you create a new business model canvas for your company?
title: Creating your own business model canvas

body:
Well done! you've learned how to create a business model around your new idea. The canvas is a really useful tool for helping you think about what's important in your business. Keep practicing those skills and it will save you time and effort in the future.


Next it's time to look at those people who might stand in the way of your idea succeeding - competitors. In the next module we will give you the tools to look at the landscape for your business, who you might be competing with and how you can get ahead.
title: You can test your idea!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

body:
Welcome back! 


In our previous modules, we have focussed on you, learning how to assess whether your idea has the potential to become a business and how to plan for the future using the Business Model Canvas.


In this module, we turn our attention outside to look at the market your business is entering and the competition it is likely to face.
title: Who else has similar ideas?

body:
In the last module, we learned how the business model canvas can help us think through a new business concept. However, to fully explore our new business idea, we need to consider other factors.Most of the factors we need to consider relate to the market in which your business will operate. 


For the rest of this module we will be looking at these factors in detail, but if you like, you can click on the boxes below for a sneak peek.

_items.body: Market size is a measure of the number of people who are potential buyers of what you sell. If you think of your business as competing for a slice of the pie, then market size measures how big that pie is.
_items.title: Market size
Trends & drivers
_items.body: Market trends are patterns in the behaviour of companies working on a particular problem. Examples include mass moves toward a new technology or business model. A market driver is any factor that causes a change in the market. Examples include a change in what people are buying or a government regulation.

Competition refers to the other companies who solve similar problems to your business. Competitors can be direct (they offer a product or service which is essentially the same as yours) or indirect (they offer a different product or service that could be used to solve the same problem).
_items.title: Competitiors
Team
_items.body: Every business has at least one founder. You will also, as you grow, be joined by some key people who take a big role in what you create and how you operate. How your team view the future and what skills they bring are essential considerations for the future.

title: Understanding your market

body:
Thinking through your market can be daunting. To help make it easier, we are going introduce a tool called the 'New Business Road Test' developed by John Mullins.


The tool is there to help you consider how big an opportunity your business represents as well as how your competitors are likely to respond.


To introduce you to the Road Test and get you comfortable with the key terms, check out the video to the right.
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Thinking through your market

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

_items.title: Number of potential buyers
_items.body:
To calculate the number of potential buyers, you need to find data on how many people exist that might face the problem you solve. Then divide that number by how many of those people you are â€˜going afterâ€™ This number is your total potential buyers.


For example, there might be three million people in the UK who want a better bank account. Of these, we might be targeting only those under 35 and living in cities. Letâ€™s say there are 200,000 of those. Those 200,000 people are your potential buyers.

To calculate how many of your potential buyers will end up buying what you offer, we need to understand how many customers other people in this market have. To do this we use â€˜market shareâ€™, which is the % of potential customers using each service. We then estimate how many customers of others could end up buying from us instead.


For example, let's say that of our 200,000 potential customers, they are evenly split between the five big banks (Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds, RBS and Santander). This means each bank has a 20% share of our market and we have none. Now letâ€™s assume that our service can tempt 2000 customers of each bank to switch. This would set our expected market share at at 5% (10000 people).
_items.title: Expected market share
Average spend per customer
_items.body:
To calculate how much our buyers will end up spending, we need to estimate the average spend per customer. We do this by using the average cost of our products and multiply this by how often the average person will buy. We then multiply this figure by our expected market share.


For example, let's say our new bank has a avg. fee of Â£3 per month for an account. This means our avg customer will spend Â£36 per year. So our expected return for the business is Â£36 multiplied by the 10,000 customers we expect to buy from us = Â£ 360,000.

body: Understanding the size of your market requires us to make a series of educated â€˜guessesâ€™. We need to guess three things: 1) How many people might need your products? 2) How many of these people do you expect to buy from you? and 3) How much, on average, will your buyers spend.
instruction: Explore the flow below to discover how to answer these three questions
title: Examining the market

_items.body:
So once you have captured your market share what do you do? Relax and eat your â€˜slice of the pieâ€™? Well not exactly! Most startups ultimately aim to grow beyond their initial customers and expand.


Expansion of your business can happen in four ways. As explained by Igor Ansoff in 1957:


  1. Penetration - You get a larger percentage of the potential customers in your market
  2. Products - You introduce new things to increase the average spending
  3. Markets - You find more people by expanding into a new country or customer type
  4. Diversification - You build a different thing for a different market (not recommended!)


You need to think carefully about what potential each of these might have for your business in the future.

Outside our own business we need to look at how circumstances in the world will will affect our business. Maybe a new law will make it harder for us to work? Perhaps, there the number of potential customers for our products is growing as populations expand?


Whatever is coming your way in the future, it pays to be prepared. As a handy guide to thinking through what might affect your business, you can use PEST. PEST stands for Political, Economic, Social and Technological drivers of change. It will help you cover the â€˜big questionsâ€™ about what might change for your business.


If you want to learn more about using PEST, follow the link here.
The first test is whether your potential customers value what you offer. If they donâ€™t find what you do valuable, they arenâ€™t likely to pay for it and you will be at a disadvantage.
_items.title: Valuable
...Rare
_items.body: The second test is whether what you has is rare. If only a very few people have what you have, it is more likely that potential customers will have to choose you if they find what you have valuable.

The final test is whether the business is set up to capture the value coming from what you offer. Even a business with a better idea will be outcompeted if it doesnâ€™t make the most of itâ€™s advantages. You will be better able to maintain your edge if you can streamline the way your business operates.
_items.title: ... and Organised to deliver value

body:
If we have identified a good opportunity then itâ€™s likely we arenâ€™t the only ones. You will undoubtedly face competition either from established businesses who currently have the customers you need or from other newcomers looking to tempt them instead.


To give ourselves the best chance we come out on top, we will need an edge over the competition. But how can we decide what gives us our edge? For something to be a competitive edge, it needs four qualities, collectively known as VRIO. Click on the boxes below to discover more about each.
title: Identifying your competitive edge

_items.body:
Well connected within the value chain


The reputation of your team is important. Often in the early days of your business, the personal relationships of your team can be key to success. Consider whether your team has developed deep customer insights on your chosen market. Also important is whether they have built up a following in the industry and whether they will be able to â€˜open doorsâ€™ for you.

Able to execute on critical success factors


You will need to rely on your team to help the business succeed. You need to consider whether the team realistically deliver the key capabilities critical to business success. Does their work reflect the standards and values you hope for in the business. Does your team have the necessary skills to deliver?

Share a common mission and a shared appetite for risk


As your business grows, it's important that you and your team all share an understanding of where you want the organisation to go. Consider whether your team are all committed to the same vision for the future. Another important test is whether your appetite for risk is similar. If one of you needs to pay rent while another is comfortable, it can cause serious tensions.

body: Your team are going to be the driving force behind your success. However, even the best teams can become ineffective if they arenâ€™t in sync with each other. John Mullins devotes three of his seven domain model to consideration of the team. Consider the following tests and think about how your team measures up?
title: Building a winning team

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


When we calculate the size of our market we should start with the number of people who fit our target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us and finally how much each will spend on average.

_feedback.correct:
Well done!


When we calculate the size of our market we should start with the number of people who fit our target audience, then how many of them we expect to buy from us and finally how much each will spend on average.

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
body: We know that when we estimate the size of the market we need to do several different calculations. But what order should we make them in?
instruction: Place the calculations in the right order then click submit
title: Measuring up your market

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


When you take the same product to a new country or type of customers Ansoff says you are pursuing a markets expansion strategy.

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!


Pursuing a markets expansion strategy is where you take the same product to a new country or type of customers!

body:
When we think about how a new business might develop in the future, there are a number of different strategies that can be pursued.


One of these strategies is to find more people by expanding into a new country of customer type.


But which of Igor Ansoff's means of expansion does this describe?
instruction: Select the answer that best matches the description and click submit.
title: Thinking about future strategy

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Your team's connections into the value chain of your market is an important check you should perform in starting a business. Where they live, their office design skills and their political opinions might make things easier, but they aren't key to success.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!


Your team's connections into the value chain of your market is an important check you should perform in starting a business. Where they live, their office design skills and their political opinions might make things easier, but they aren't key to success.

_items.text: Is my team able to execute on critical success factors?
Does my team all live in the same neighbourhood?
Do my team understand how to lay out an office?
Does my team agree with me on politics

displayTitle: Assessing the strengths of your team
body:
As we learned, there are some simple checks you can do to make sure your time is positioned for success.


Which of the following is one of those simple checks?
instruction: Select your answer then click submit.
title: Assessing the strengths of your team

body:
Good job! You've learned how to assess the market for a new business venture. The road test is a great companion to the business model canvas we learned about in module two. We recommend filling one in and to help you consider these important points


Next it's time to go back to the drawing board. YouAs you go through the development of any new business, you will need to think up good ideas about your products, your business model and your next moves. Our next module will help you learn how to better manage your ideas and decide which ones work.
displayTitle: You can get to grips with your market!
title: You can get to grips with your market!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Can I talk to my customers?
body:
In the modules of this course so far, we have been all about you and your idea. But if your idea is to become a business, sooner or later you will need customers. 


These customers have to like what you offer enough to use and often pay for it. This means we need to test our ideas out with them before we commit ourselves fully.
title: Can I talk to my customers?

body:
Many entrepreneurs trip up when talking to customers. They fail to ask good questions so they donâ€™t get good answers. What we need is a structure to help us get the most from these conversations. 


A good way to structure your questions is by using Rob Fitzpatrickâ€™s â€˜Mom Testâ€™. The testâ€™s three principles will help you ask better questions: 1) Talk about their life instead of your idea 2) Ask about specifics in the past instead of opinions about the future and 3) Talk less and listen more.
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more about the 'Mom Test'...
title: Giving your conversations structure

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

_items.body:
Hi, my name is...


A few brief introductory and biographical questions to put the customer at ease


Example: Can you tell me a little bit about your business?

What's the problem?


Two or three questions about when the person might have faced the problem your idea solves. Ask about occasions when they face that problem and how that problem affects them.


Example: 'Tell me about the last time you ... and when this occurs, how much additional time or money does it cost you?â€™

Tell me more...


These are â€˜dig deeperâ€™ questions to keep your interviewee talking about the problem


Example: When this occurs, how much additional time or money does it cost your company?

Can I call you?


These bring the interview to a close and let the person know how they can stay involved with your work.


Example: Would you be willing to help us by participating in some user research?

Treasured memories


Not a part of the interview but something to do straight away. Write down your results as soon as possible. You donâ€™t want to forget important things by waiting until later!

body:
Using the Mom Test as a guide, we now need to build a script for our interviews. This script will have all the main questions you plan to ask. It really useful for keeping to time as well.


While there are lots of ways you can create a script, we recommend using the following structure from Ash Mauryaâ€™s book Running Lean.
title: Asking the right questions

displayTitle: Who should I be talking to?
body:
Even with a great script, you still need to talk to the right type of people. In the universe of possible customers for your product or service, some customer contacts are much more useful than others. This handy ranking from Steve Blank tells you what to look for from least valuable to most:


  1. Those who have the problem - but are not aware of the fact, it doesn't trouble them in getting their jobs done.
  2. Those who are aware of the problem, but view it as a low level nuisance or irritation that is not worth expending energy to resolve.
  3. Those who have been actively seeking a solution.
  4. Those who have taken some action to patch together at least some parts of a solution.
  5. Those who in addition have or can acquire a budget.
title: Who should I be talking to?

_items.body:
Friends & family


Even if your close family and friends can't help, youâ€™ll often find someone in their networks who fits your target customer profile. Use referrals from people you know to reach those you want to speak to.

Social networking


Networks like Facebook and twitter can help you reach people fast. However, if you drown people in requests, they will quickly start ignoring you. Reach out specifically to people for a better result.

Communities

Places like meetup.com are great sources for finding groups of target customers. Beware these communities can be close knit and not always receptive to others straight away. You will need to build up trust before you reach out with an idea.

Professional networks 


Online professional tools like Linkedin can be a quick way to find people who fit the bill. You can look for individuals in specific roles or organisations and plot a route to reach them using shared connections.

Publishing content


What about creating a blog to get interested parties to come to you? This provides an opportunity to establish you as a voice and someone people will tune in to. However, be careful to keep your content fresh otherwise users wonâ€™t show up.

Online research


Q&A sites like Quora can help you tap into a community to find potential customers. If you can provide high quality insights related to your business area then you can build up a following.

body: Even if you know how to get the most from your customer conversations, how do you know where they are? Finding customers usually requires you to search through several sources. Explore the graphic below to learn more about each source.
instruction: Click on each '+' button to discover more
title: Finding your customers

body:
Once you have feedback from your customers, you need to decide what to do with it. What do we do when customer are telling you something that contradicts your thinking? When customer feedback doesnâ€™t line up with your idea, you have three options:


  • Keep going - If you keep going, you run the risk that your customers wonâ€™t value what you offer so in most cases, you should avoid this option.
  • Back to the drawing board - You may decide that this idea just doesnâ€™t work for people. Thatâ€™s okay. Better to discard it now than invest in something people donâ€™t value.
  • Pivot - You may decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem. If you decide to pursue that new version of the idea, it is called â€˜pivotingâ€™.
title: Acting on your feedback

body: Rob Fitzpatrick's 'Mom Test' is a good way to make sure your customer conversations stay on track. The test has three principles. But what are they?
instruction: Select all the options that match then hit submit!

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


The three principles of the 'Mom Test' are to talk about their life instead of your idea, ask about past specifics instead of future opinions & talk less and listen more

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s Right!


The three principles of the 'Mom Test' are to talk about their life instead of your idea, ask about past specifics instead of future opinions & talk less and listen more

_items.text: Talk about their life instead of your idea, ask about past specifics instead of future opinions & talk less and listen more
Keep the conversation going at all costs, don't be afraid to tell lies & always promote yourself
Try to look bored with their answers, don't give away your secrets & attempt to talk them out of buying

title: Passing the 'Mom Test'

Those are some great sources of new customer connections.

title: Finding your customers

Are you sure about that?


When you decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem and pursue that new version of the idea, it is called â€˜pivotingâ€™.

_feedback.correct:
That's Right!


When you decide that what customers are telling you gives you a different way to solve their problem and pursue that new version of the idea, it is called â€˜pivotingâ€™.

body: There are three ways you can respond to negative feedback. You could carry on, go back to the drawing board or change course. But what is that change of course called in startup speak?
instruction: Select your answer then click 'Submit'
title: Making feedback count

body:
Awesome job! Now you have the tools to go out and hold great customer conversations. By applying the 'Mom Test' and scripting your questions in advance, you can make sure you get the most from every chat.


So now you have your customer feedback there is one more thing to consider: can this idea become a product? In our final module we will work through how to assess the idea's potential.
title: You can talk to customers!

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?
body:
Nice to see you! First we need to tackle the big question: Do I have what it takes to start a business? 


Let's start by getting one thing clear. Nobody can say for sure if your idea can become a successful business. If you want to find out, you have to try.


But there are ways to better predict your chances. Below you can out how to ask and answer the three big questions about any business idea: why this idea? why me? and why now?
title: Do I have what it takes for a digital business?

displayTitle: Giving your idea a reality check
body:
As the venture capitalist Vinod Khosla said: 'Nobody will pay you for solving a non-problem.'


So can you decide if you idea is a problem worth solving? There are three main reality checks your idea needs to pass. Click on the boxes below to find out more.

_items.body: Your idea needs to solve a clear need that people have. Your first reality check is to find out whether people actually face the problem you are aiming to solve.
_items.title: Desirability
Feasability
_items.body: You need to have the confidence that you can deliver, or will be able to, on the solution you imagine. Your second reality check is to consider if you will be able to solve the problem people are facing.

You need to make sure the cost of solving people's problem is less than they are willing to pay. Your final reality check is to consider whether you can cover the costs of solving the problem from what you expect to be paid.
_items.title: Viability

title: Giving your idea a reality check

body: Even if your idea passes the reality check, itâ€™s likely someone else had a similar thought. These are potential competitors. For any business to be successful, it needs to do something different to its competitors. That difference is why customers will choose you over them. To decide what to do differently, you will need a value proposition. A valuae proposition is your solution to your customer's problem. A good one will say how you solve the probelm and why your solution is the best available.
displayTitle: Making sure your idea is unique
instruction: Click the video on the right to learn more...
title: Making sure your idea is unique

_audio.ariaLabel: This button will play an audio description of the video

_media.ariaLabel: This button will play the video

displayTitle: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you
body:
You may have a great idea, but are you the person who should be making it into a business? After all being an entrepreneur isnâ€™t for everyone. So how can you decide if this idea is a good match for you?


There are some key traits many startup founders share. Scroll through them below and think about how many you have.

_items.title: Seeking opportunity
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs see problems as opportunities. They also don't like leaving these opportunities for someone else to pursue.


Do you look at problems in your life and instantly think about how to solve them?

_items.title: Taking risks before security
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs take a risk on a future business rather than looking for a safe job today.


Are you a 'poker player' who is willing to take measured risks to secure future returns?

Entrepreneurs fail often but never let that failure deter them.


Do you have the desire to experiment, fail and keep going?
_items.title: Tolerating Failure
Creatively leveraging resources
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs often have to do without the right talent and improvise solutions with what they have.


Do you have the ability to get what you need from your friends and network?

_items.title: Tenacity to overcome obstacles and push an idea to implementation
_items.body:
Entrepreneurs regularly have to deal with doubt and uncertainty over their future.


Do you have the passion and persistence to learn from the inevitable set-backs and drive ideas into action?

title: Assessing if this business is a good fit for you

_items.body:
Victor Hugo said â€˜Nothing is as powerful as an idea whose time has comeâ€™. So how can you figure out if this is the right time for your business?


Successful businesses can spot can spot when a change creates new opportunities. Nokia was originally a paper mill, Sony sold radios and Mitel was a maker of lawnmowers. All of them saw a change and identified an opportunity to succeed.


For your idea to be successful, you will need to think carefully about this. What has changed in the world that will influence people to buy from you? It might be that you offer a brand new technology, solve a new problem or make something more affordable and practical.


Whatever the change, you need to be clear on how the world today will contribute to making your business a success. Having a clear answer to this question will boost your odds of success.

body: Can you find all the criteria that you would use to give your new business idea a reality check?
instruction: Select all the options that match then hit submit!

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s Right!


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Desirability (does anyone need it?), Feasibility (can we do it?) and Viability (do we have the resources to make it work?) are the essential reality checks for any new idea.

title: Taking a reality check

body: Earlier we learned how a value proposition helps you nail down your idea. But how would you define the idea if someone asked you?
instruction: Fill in the blanks in the sentence below then hit submit

_feedback.correct:
Thatâ€™s right!


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


A value proposition is your solution to a customerâ€™s problem. There are lots of other ways of putting this but thinking about a solution and a problem is an easy way to remember!

title: Nailing that value proposition

displayTitle: Taking a look in the mirror
body: While every entrepreneur is different, many share a particular set of traits. Can you match up the names of the trait to their descriptions?

_feedback.correct:

You know those skills like the back of your hand!

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Have another go!
_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?


Those qualities don't seem to match up with their descriptions. Hit 'show answer' to check out our definitions.

_dropZones.text: You look at problems and see the solutions
You are willing to take a risk for a future return
You can improvise solutions where none exist
You move on fast from your mistakes

title: Taking a look in the mirror

body:
Well done! you've finished your first module.

Everything we've learnt above is important when considering if your idea has what it takes to become a business. We recommend taking some time to consider why this idea? why me? why now? and what next? They will give you the foundation on which your business is built.


So what happens once you have answers you need? The next thing you need is to structure your answers into something you can use. In the next module we will give you the skills to turn your idea into a business model you can share with others.
title: You have what it takes!
